body:
Hi @PierreOreistein - thanks for raising the issue! 

Looks like this is due to the newer version of pmdarima. We're currently working on a new release where we will update our dependencies (#538). That should solve this error.

Hi @mloning ,

Thanks for the answer. Can't wait to see the new release!

By the way, sktime is a great piece of code! Thanks for your hard work on it

issue.title: Add tests for forecasting with exogenous variables

labels.name: maintenance
labels.description: Continuous integration, unit testing & package distribution

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

body: Hi @PierreOreistein @mloning   I have a confusion I thought arima is a pure time series method and its prediction of anything using arima depends only on the past values of that parameter. But here in sktime AutoARIMA you are also feeding x_train along with y_train I wanted to understand, what effect does these x_train has on the y_hat(prediction of y)? does AutoARIMA considers other features while making the forecast for y?

@Pranav-India, it's a direct interface (with different signature) to `pmdarima`'s `AutoARIMA`. The exogeneous variables are used as regressors, see the [`pmdarima` reference](https://alkaline-ml.com/pmdarima/modules/generated/pmdarima.arima.auto_arima.html).

Hi @fkiraly  Thank you for the response , I read the page you have mentioned it cleared my understanding. What I did is I tried AutoArima predictions with both the models 


`import pmdarima as pm`
`from pmdarima import model_selection`
`import numpy as np`
`from matplotlib import pyplot as plt`

`arima = pm.auto_arima(y_tr,X=x_tr, start_p=1, start_q=1,`
 `test='adf',  ` # use adftest to find optimal 'd'
 ` max_p=3, max_q=3, ` # maximum p and q
 ` m=1, ` # frequency of series
 ` d=None, ` # let model determine 'd'
 `  seasonal=True,`   # No Seasonality
  ` start_P=0,` 
 ` D=1, `
  ` trace=True,`
 ` error_action='ignore',  `
  `  suppress_warnings=True,` 
 ` stepwise=True)`


![pdarima](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/55158029/129142957-617dd4dd-0e62-4f49-b0b6-a10bad1decb6.png)


`fh_train = ForecastingHorizon(y_tr.index, is_relative=False)`
`fh = ForecastingHorizon(y_te.index, is_relative=False)`
        
`forecaster = AutoARIMA()`
`forecaster.fit(y_tr,x_tr)`
`y_pred_train = forecaster.predict(fh_train , X=x_tr)`
`y_pred = forecaster.predict(fh , X=x_te)`
`df = pd.DataFrame(y_tr.append(y_pred,ignore_index = True))`
![sktimeautoarima](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/55158029/129142947-0727de03-8b12-4f8a-8b2d-e333921a6ac7.png)



I checked the summary of both models it is exactly the same all the values are exactly same also I have made sure that the input and output data is also exactly same still I am getting pretty different results. Does sktime make some more changes to the output of pmdarima's autoarima ? 

I went through [this](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/main/sktime/forecasting/arima.py#L357-L576) git page of sktime AutoArima but could not understand what improvement sktime makes on output of pmdarima. Can you please point to the correct direction so I can find the complete implementation? 


Thank you

>I went through this git page of sktime AutoArima but could not understand what improvement sktime makes on output of pmdarima. Can you please point to the correct direction so I can find the complete implementation?

`sktime`'s autoARIMA is simply interfacing `pmdarima`'s, i.e., the algorithm is exactly the same.

What `sktime` adds is the `scikit-learn` like interface (which `pmdarima` doesn't have), for instance you can use AutoARIMA with the same interface as all the other methods, or use it in pipelines etc.

The file you link to is the right one, but the lines are not correct - you need to look at the `AutoARIMA` class.

>I checked the summary of both models it is exactly the same all the values are exactly same also I have made sure that the input and output data is also exactly same still I am getting pretty different results.

There is some stochasticity in the forecasts and fitting of `AutoARIMA`, so that might be an explanation. If you re-run, your results might be different each time, for the same method.
It would be good if you could check whether this stochastic fluctuations are the reason - if not, there may be a bug in the interface which we'd be thankful to hear about (in case you can confirmed it).
(if you think the deviation is a bug, and you don't know where it comes from: would appreciate some reproducible code that creates the figures)
@fkiraly  Sure I rerun the code the results are still same I will let you know if I find something
Hi @fkiraly I wanted to know this in "ThetaForecaster" , does sktime ignores X = x_tr i.e. exogenous variables? or it is using them for regression?
